posts.cooked: I’m using a through bore encoder for get the position of an elevator. The way I understand it, the class we should use is the DutyCycleEncoder. I’m a bit confused on how to convert the 0-1 value to get the absolute position of the encoder. It was mentioned to us that PID might be a better way to accomplish but I’m not sure how to set that up either. Any help would be appreciated and many thanks in advance.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
How are you wiring the encoder (like where does it plug into?  What motor/motor controller are you using to drive the elevator?

If wired to a Rio DIO port, then yes, the DutyCycleEncoder is the class to use.  WPILib docs are your friend for how to use that class.

We can provide more specific advice (including what to do with the 0-1 range) after knowing how its all designed/wired.

posts.name: Kayla Toll
posts.cooked: I think you’re saying that the value you get back from the encoder is a float or double between zero and one. If you take that and multiply by 360, it’ll be in degrees. Maybe that’ll be easier for you to work with?

Yes it’s plugged into the roborio dio port like the image bellow. The motor for the elevator is a neo vortex. IMG_7741 1040×500 61.6 KB

IMG_7741 1040×500 61.6 KB

IMG_7741 1040×500 61.6 KB

I’m not sure the exact terminology ( sorry if that’s caused any confusion so far ). I want to be able to get the total rotation of the encoder in a unit like rotations or degrees depending on what’s simplest, and I’m not sure exactly how to do that.
There is an issue reading DutyCycleEncoders on the RIO. You need to wait 2 seconds after initialization before reading

posts.name: Tori Dell
posts.cooked:
Check out WPILib’s documentation on DutyCycleEncoders and the class’s API documentation for more info, but basically the 0-1 value is by default representing one rotation. Keep in mind that this is an absolute position, so if the encoder rotates 1.5 times it will read 0.5. If you do not want this, use a different wiring configuration as a quadrature encoder.

You should be able to set a different value to output in the constructor (with the fullRange parameter) or you can multiply the output by whatever you desire after getting it (x360 to get degrees).

Make sure you configure with the setDutyCycleRange method to get accurate results. You can find the specs for it here .

link_counts.title: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Tori Dell
posts.cooked:
Jakeb:

It was mentioned to us that PID might be a better way to accomplish but I’m not sure how to set that up either.

PID is kind-of separate from reading the absolute encoder value, meaning that you don’t have to choose between them. To put it simply, it is a method of determining how much power to give the motor that drives your elevator depending on how far it is from where you want it instead of always moving at a constant speed. Check out WPILib’s PID control docs if you want to learn more, as it is probably a good idea to implement if you can.

link_counts.title: PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: I’m a bit confused on which class to use. There seems to be two options: SparkClosedLoopController ( revlib ) and PIDController ( wpilib ). Is one of these a better choice? Our code is built on top of the rev swerve code template which uses those closed loop controller.

posts.name: Tori Dell
posts.cooked: It seems like according to REV’s documentation , the SparkClosedLoopController is only able to control its attached Spark motor controller, which I would stick with if that’s all that you are using to control your elevator. Otherwise, if you are using a different motor controller, you have to use WPILib’s PIDController.
